title: What 5 songs are the most played of all time? - Quora

response.answer_text: Strap in… This may be a surprise. When it comes to “The most played song of all time,” it depends how you measure things. Lets look at a few of history’s contenders. We’ll call a “song,” a “tune with lyrics”.We’ll also aggregate the meaning of “play” to include “performed,” “sung” and “presented on any media”.For a long time, the most played and performed song of all time was “Happy Birthday”. The melody was adapted from 1912’s “Good Morning To All”.  Image: The “most played melody.” Credit: Happy Birthday to You. Warner Chappell bought the rights holders, Birch Tree Group for USD$25m in 1988 and for a quarter-century, made more than $2m every year from licensing copyright and performance.  After a landmark court case in 2013, Warner settled with licensees of the song for $14m. “Happy Birthday” has been in the public domain ever since. For a long time, “Happy Birthday” would have been the most played song of all time.  Over the last few decades, Disney also laid claim to the most played song—“It’s a Small World.”  The amusement ride theme, played worldwide at the Paris, Tokyo, Shanghai and US parks, has 50 million radio plays, including ads.  If we include performances by struggling guitar players, covers bands and singers as well as plays across all media? There’s a song which has to be considered: Led Zeppelin’s 1971 epic, “Stairway to Heaven.”  Before modern music distribution systems there were other “most played contenders”: Chubby Checker, “The Twist”;The Righteous Brothers, “You’ve Lost that Lovin’ Feelin’,” and “Unchained Melody”;The Eagles, “Hotel California”;Pink Floyd, “Comfortably Numb”;Queen, “Bohemian Rhapsody”;The Beatles, “Yesterday”.These all earned gongs for “most played song” and still make the list today.  Now that music media has brought product into homes across the world via the internet, the “music game” has fundamentally changed. Spotify has made it clear that one song has eclipsed most others by an order of magnitude with two billion plays.  Add other media? Ed Sheeran has a candidate: “Shape of You.” The song has 4¼ billion plays on YouTube alone.  Which brings us to today’s “most played song” of all time. The song was first released in 2017—by latin / reggaeton singer, Luis Fonsi and rapper, Daddy Yankee. Latin music dwarfs other genres worldwide for both sales and plays. After a 2017 remix cover by Justin Bieber, “Despacito” was re-released by the Puerto Rican duo this year, 2019.  With near 6½ billion plays on YouTube, add streaming media, broadcast, radio delivery and performance? “Despacito” (“Slowly”) is as of right now, the most played song of all time.  The next ten years will be hard for older fans and fans of the old. Rihanna is about to eclipse the Beatles’ total sales records.Drake has smashed most artist’s No. 1’s already.U2 will beat the Stones’ tix numbers if they can hold it together.Beyoncé will get the gross concert turnover marks.The artist who will outshine them all is likely alive already. —My answer to, “What band has sold the most concert tickets of all time?” I’ve said before, “it’s called the music business for a reason.” Answers like these attract enormous controversy. Diehard fans with a lifetime of memories look back to a past which can’t possibly equal the future. Music distribution has radically changed. So too, has the “most played song.”

There are lots of good answers here; some listed five, some listed a lot more. I want to list just one that I did not see in any of the answers. I would like to nominate “Turkey in the Straw.” Quite a hillbilly song; sounds good on a harmonica, a banjo, and even a mouth harp. It got played at square dances and get togethers. But its biggest run was on the ice cream truck. In my own home town, it was played repeatedly on the ice cream scooter as it rounded every block in town, every day, over and over and over. In high school, desperate for a job, I drove it for three weeks one summer, and it played all night while I slept. I finally decided that poverty was better than insanity. I moved to other towns because of college and a job, and was surprised to find that “Turkey in the Straw” was a favorite of ice cream trucks and scooters all over the area I grew up. It may not still be in the top five, as times have changed. There are less ice cream trucks now, less kids outside playing on a hot summer day with a nickel available, and less people willing to drive a scooter all day for minimum wage. On top of that, this past summer, I was in my home town, visiting my parents, and did my mile at the local park. I heard the melody of an ice cream truck, and realized that something was wrong. As it got closer, I realized that everything had changed. It was playing “La Cucuracha.”
